awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Scale-dependent processes as the drivers for understanding range- and niche-expansion in a widespread native species
awd_abstract_narration:
Eastern Red Cedar (Juniperus virginiana) is native to the eastern United States, where this attractive tree has been a popular choice for landscaping. But out in the Great Plains, Red Cedar is known as the "green glacier", because this slow-growing species is taking over once-productive grasslands. Ranchers face substantial economic costs in removing Red Cedar from grazing lands, and it reduces grassland biodiversity through competition with native species. But how do you stop a "green glacier"? Populations might be expanding because environmental variability has altered frost and drought regimes, or because humans have implemented prairie management practices such as fire suppression, or even because of changes in the migration patterns of seed-dispersing birds. It is more likely, however, that many factors are at work. For example, environmental variability might allow plants to move into a new region, but seed dispersal by birds could promote population expansion within a region. Rather than focus on one factor, this study will determine the relative importance of several causal factors. Data from experiments will be used in a model that predicts the rate and locations where Red Cedar range expansion is likely to occur. Findings will be presented to the public at the Holden Arboretum Scientist Lecture Series and incorporated into Holden Arboretum's "Working with Nature" K-12 Camp and "Tree Corp" adult workforce development program.  

Uncovering scale-dependent mechanisms controlling range and niche expansion of plants is a key issue in biodiversity research. This work integrates physiological and ecological processes across scales to determine the potential for further range expansion. The central hypothesis is that, at a large spatial scale, changes in prairie management are more important than physiological climate tolerance for promoting range expansion, while at smaller scales, biotic factors such as avian dispersal, competition and facilitation are more important. The spatial scale of variation will be determined using microsatellites in historical, encroaching and niche expanding populations. The effects of fire will be examined using long-term data from the Konza Prairie NSF-LTER, while manipulative and field experiments will determine how the interaction of frost and drought impact Red Cedar performance. Seed dispersal by birds and changes in bird migration over time will be examined to determine how far, and where, birds disseminate Red Cedar. Empirical data will be integrated into a spatially explicit population-level age/stage matrix model, based on inputs from structural equation modeling at all three spatial scales, with spatial resolution determined by the results of microsatellite studies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Eastern Red Cedar (ERC) is a common tree native to America. In the past decades it has been reported to rapidly expand its distribution, from its original populations mostly at the Southeast US. Such rapid range expansion is an important phenomenon, not limited to ERC. To study the causes of this range expansion, we studied what affects the population of ERC. Specifically, its growth and survival rates in response to stresses such as drought, cold and fire, the establishment of its seedlings pacing competition by other trees and grasses, and the maximal distance that the seeds can move when dispersed by birds. 

We conducted a series of common-garden and green-house experiments for seedling and young trees, as well as expanded sampling campaign for ERC in Ohio and throughout the US.

We found ERC to be drought tolerant. Our data show that previous estimates of ERC drought tolerance based on the conductivity woody tissues (a measure for how easy it is for water, in the form of sap, to move up the tree stem) misrepresent actual plant drought response. ERC plants from more arid sites exhibit a more exploitative water use strategy, which could promote expansion by facilitating rapid water uptake in seasonal rain pulse-driven systems, while a decrease in hydraulic conductance in shoots could promote survival by preventing hydraulic failure of more costly woody tissue.

We found that individuals originating from the warmer, more southern range edge were initially not as cold-hardy as plants from the other source populations and that they only reached similar hardiness after prolonged low temperatures. We did not find an effect of drought on cold-hardiness, consistent with a high level of drought tolerance in ERC.  

We found that ERC created a negative plant-soil feedback that limited the growth of some cool season grasses, reducing their overall biomass by >60%. The limitation of grass growth in sterile soils indicates redcedar may exude a chemical into the soil that limits grass growth. By creating a plant-plant interaction that negatively affects competitors, redcedars increase the probability of seedling survival until they can grow to overtop their neighbors. 

We found that shade was the most important factor limiting the growth rates and biomass of ERC. There were significant declines in plant size, health and nutrient content when shaded. These results are consistent with the notion that the ERC is a pioneer forest species, and that shade is the reason that these redcedars are replaced by other tree species. We found that a single fire had a negative effect on young trees. There was no significant effect of competition with grass, perhaps because the competitive effect was shading by grasses and not nutrient depletion. Overall, the effects of shade were far more apparent than the effects of fire.

We found that when faced with competition by grasses or other trees, ERC saplings adjust their root distribution and consume water from deeper soil layers. Regardless, ERC saplings had less total biomass and higher mortality when they grew with competitors. Root overlap and partitioning can affect how ERC perform and adapt to new competitors and can allow their co-existence with grasses and other woody species, which can facilitate their encroachment into grasslands and woodlands. Our data also show that competition could limit establishment, regardless of water availability.

We developed an approach to estimate the maximal movement speed of migrating birds that eat and disperse ERC seeds. These estimation use point location data of presence/absence reported commonly to public datasets such as E-Bird. 

Training and professional development have been provided for eight high school students and one teacher at Franklinton high school in Ohio on a weekly basis for three summers. One graduate served as a math mentor for the Franklinton High School students.

Two undergraduate students at Denison University were trained in R programming and ecological data analysis. 

Five graduate students in Kent State, and two postdocs at the Holden Arboretum were trained in advanced modeling, analysis, and field measurement techniques. 

Videographer David Smeltzer has been actively continuing to produce video of all participants and in situ observation of ERC at all sites. He shall be continuing his videography in the eastern redcedar-encroached areas of Nebraska. He shall complete this project in 2023/2024. Sample video on our eastern redcedar project: https://vimeo.com/408954052.

Code for co-PI Sarah Supp openly developed on GitHub: https://github.com/sarahsupp/ERC-bird-dispersal

We have provided an outreach publication at the Holden Arboretum online blog: Ortiz (2022) Electronic Herbaria Data Applications, a Prelude to Study Eastern Redcedar Encroachment in the US Great Plains and Midwest https://holdenfg.org/blog/electronic-herbaria-data-applications-a-prelude-to-study-eastern-redcedar-encroachment-in-the-us-great-plains-and-midwest/
